description: From Middle English windle, windel, from Old English windel (“basket”), from Proto-Germanic *windilaz (“wrap; diaper; plaitwork; basket”), equivalent to wind +‎ -le. Related to Old English windan (“to wind, twist”).

entries.meaning: An old English measure of corn, half a bushel.
examples: In the Derby household book of 1561, wheat, malt, and oats are sold by the quarter and the windle, in which the quarter clearly contained sixteen windles, and must have been a wholly different measure from that which we are familiar.

definitionGroups.group: Any dried-out grass leaf or stalk in a field

entries.meaning: Also any of several species of grasses that leave such leaves or stalks, such as dog-tail grass, Plantago lanceolata
A reel for winding something into a bundle, such as winding string or yarn into skeins or straw into bundles.

verbs.description: windle (third-person singular simple present windles, present participle windling, simple past and past participle windled)
